entry.title: 我的爷爷奶奶
entry.content:
我最可爱的爷爷奶奶

乡下长大的孩子，大部分都是被爷爷奶奶带大的，我也不例外。于是爷爷奶奶成了我最亲近的人，也是我最最最爱的人。

我爷爷今年83岁，我奶奶今年74岁。爷爷年轻时就犯了头痛的毛病。70岁开始，每逢过年会问我和妹妹同一个问题：现在我身体不好，不知道还能不能多坐几年，你们说爷爷还能多坐一年吗？” 我和妹妹总是回答：“放心，还能的”。他脸上笑开了花，说：“那我就还多坐几年蛮，你们也可以多拿些压岁钱”。转眼间，爷爷从70岁活到了83岁，虽然过的辛苦，但还活着。

长这么大，我第一次见爷爷哭在两年前，那时他的妹妹去世，杨华阿姨回来挂纸，我们一起吃饭，吃着吃着，爷爷毫无征兆地哭了起来，拿着筷子的手抹着眼泪，接着说：“我的兄弟姐妹差不多都去了，没想到就剩我一个了”。杨华阿姨赶忙安慰说：“不要想那些，这是您的福份，好好保护身体，多坐几年，我们好孝顺孝顺您”。爷爷又小声念叨了几遍相同的话，杨华阿姨一直在旁安慰，爷爷才逐渐安静下来吃饭。

那时我开始意识到以及担心能与老人相处的日子越来越少，他们一辈子没能留下几张照片。现在是时候写点关于爷爷奶奶的日常，留下回忆。这是我最可爱的爷爷奶奶。

辛苦了一辈子，不值得的一辈子

爷爷奶奶于解放前出生，过了一辈子的苦日子。老来应该是享清福的时候，却在70多岁仍在干农活，种地、卖菜、砍柴、养生计，自己能做的都做。爷爷将近77、78时，因为身体实在不能干了，加上家里人劝，才逐渐不去揽这些事，奶奶目前还经营着菜地。我们总劝他们年纪这么大，不要做了。而他们总念叨着：“自己能做一点，得一点”。土地于他们是一切。

农村老人的情形大都如此，一些甚至等死亡到来时才停手。能享清福的老人太少太少，我一只手都能数过来。造成这种情形的原因有三，一是：农村的家庭情况差，多一个人干活，意味着少一分家庭负担，老人总是为子女着想，能做一点做一点，子女不用那么辛苦；二是：得有孝敬的子女，在农村难有孝敬子女；三是，就算有孝敬的子女，老人劳碌惯了，让他们不干活，坐不住。

奶奶总是说：“刘杨（我小名）啊，我们是苦了一辈子嘞，还是你们过得快活。我这一辈子字不认得几个，自己的名字都不会写，电视不会拨，手机不会拨，什么都不会，叫我去远的地方又不敢去，也没坐过次高铁、飞机，我也怕这些东西，不敢坐。不像你们什么地方都去了，什么都体验过了哦！你爷爷也到处都去嗨噶了，但我这一辈子是真的过得没值。。。”

夜色中

多年过去了，我仍时常想起这个画面：乡村的晚上，没有人，没有光，只能靠听，听河水声，听风吹过树叶的沙沙声，听虫鸣声，听零星几辆车驶过的声音。他站在夜色中，身子朝着往县城的路，望着，等着，盼着他的孙儿回来。

我的情绪依旧和当时那般复杂和翻涌。在那一片夜色中，我对牵挂这种感情第一次有了一个具象化的理解。

读高中前，我的世界只有县城那么大。初中会考成绩出来后，班主任和我说：市一中在招生，免学费，另外每个月发300块钱的生活费，你去试试吧“。想着不用待在那个小小的县城，还能看看更大的世界，于是我便去了市里读书。

去报道没几天就不中用地开始想家。某个周五的下午学校临时接到通知，说要放假，和我同一个县城的都是些念家崽，听到突如其来说要放假，开心的不行，提议说我们现在回家吧。从学校回家要坐3趟车：先坐公交到市汽车站，接着坐汽车回县城，然后从县城坐车回乡下。我打电话告诉爷爷奶奶我今天回来，爷爷笑着说道：“那你回来自己小心点，这晚上有车回来吗？” 我说：“到了县城，我再搭个摩托车回来，你放心咯”。

从学校出来已经下午5点多钟了，回县城的路上，由于前面发生事故，班车不得动，半个小时过去还停在原地，期间爷爷打电话过来问怎么还没到。又等了半个小时路才通。回县城原来只需50分钟的车程，那天搞了2个小时。

回到县城后，我搭了个摩托车。县城依水而建，依水而居，摩托车从县城回我家是沿着河旁公路开。乡间的路上，只能靠着摩托车的前灯看清楚东西，快到家的时候，摩托车前灯照出一个小小的身影，我立马认出了那是爷爷，看着他身子微微蜷缩，默默地站在夜色中等我，我情绪翻涌、眼泪在眼睛里打转。那人大声的说：“是刘杨吗？” “爷爷，是我” ，我回答到。我对摩托车师傅说：“麻烦你就送到这儿吧”。下车后，我长舒口气，说：“不用出来接我嘞，你怎么电筒也不开站在这儿，等很久了吗？”。爷爷说：“你奶奶担心你这么晚还没回来，叫我来河边大马路上来等你，怕你看不见亮”。“这有几步路，没事的”，我答到。然后我把手搭在爷爷的肩上，一起走回了家。

第三次，遇见奶奶

读书的时候他们念叨你的学业，毕业后主题换成了：有没有女朋友？什么时候结婚？什么时候生小孩让他们抱重孙。爷爷奶奶看着和我一起长大的发小一个个结婚，他们愁得不行，“怎么没见你有动静？” 奶奶问。“我是不急呀，那我要到30岁才结婚”，我回答。奶奶带着点火气，把声音上扬说道：你不急咯，你看下那家屋里的，年轻的时候屁股后面跟着一群妹仔，没急，现在40岁了还没结婚，他妈给他介绍带着崽的女嘞，他又看不上，对他妈说：’你要是喜欢，自己娶，我是没要’。年轻的妹仔又看不上他。而且我也没看到你现在屁股后面有妹仔跟着你，我看你攒劲没急咯，到时候讨老婆都讨不到”！

毕业后2年听老人念了2年，今年我去相了亲，回家的时候自然可以听爷爷回忆他年轻时候的这些事。

爷爷笑着说：“……，我相亲了三次，才遇到你现在的奶奶。我当兵回来后，隔壁的阿姨想把她妹崽介绍给我。但我晓得她女和三个人和起，一下和这个小伙子搭一下，一下又和那个小伙子搭一下，我就不想要，后来阿姨生病要走了硬想把女嫁给我，我给了她20多块钱，我和她说：’我身上就这么多钱，你拿去，先看能不能治好病吧‘。那时候20多块钱值钱，吃碗面才1毛多钱吧。然后我就跑出去了，撒了个谎让战友写封信回来说我在河里被溺死了，不用记着我了，结果把我的那几个兄弟姐妹哭“死”了，以为我真死了，这是第一段。第二个，她爸爸妈妈在单位上班，她是老师，我们快成的时候，那时候闹起了革命，说她爸爸妈妈是地主，要把他们赶回邵阳的乡窝窝里去。她哭着说：’我舍不得爸妈，我要一起回去，不能把他们丢在那边，对不起’。第二段这样不了了之。第三次，遇到了你的奶奶，那时候她家里贫困，屋在乡里，我跑过去的时候，她穿着补丁的衣服躲在堂屋门口的后面，流着鼻涕。后来我们谈了一个月结了婚”。

entry.title: Naval's Qoutes on Learning
entry.content:
You must never, ever fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool.

--- By Richard Feynman

Cultivate Desire of Learn

  • “The ability to learn, the means of learning, the tools of learning, are aboundant and infinite. It’s the desire that’s incredibly scarce.

Learning By Understanding

I don’t know what’s the matter with people: they don’t learn by understanding; they learn by some other way—by rote or something. Their knowledge is so fragile!

--- By Richard Feynman

  • "True Wisdom comes from understanding, Not Memorazition"

  • "It's much better to know the the basics from the ground up and have a solid fundation of understanding than it is to have a scaffolding where you're just memorizing advanced concepts."

Learning The Basics

  • "I know people who read 100 regurgitated books on evolution and they've never read Darwin."

  • "I think learning should be about learning the basics in all fields and learning then really well over and over. Life is mostly about applying basics and only doing the advanced stuff in the things that you are truly love and where you understand the basics inside out."

entry.title: 如何理解贝叶斯定理
entry.content:
贝叶斯定理

由条件概率得：

P(a∩b)=P(b)×P(a∣b)=p(a)×P(b∣a)P(a \cap b) = P(b) \times P(a \mid b) = p(a) \times P(b \mid a) P(a∩b)=P(b)×P(a∣b)=p(a)×P(b∣a)

将P(a∣b)P(a \mid b)P(a∣b)移到等式右边，推导出贝叶斯定理：

P(a∣b) =P(a)×P(b∣a)P(b)P(a \mid b) \ = \frac{P(a) \times P(b \mid a)}{P(b)} P(a∣b) =P(b)P(a)×P(b∣a)​

其中 P(b)=P(b∣a)P(a)+P(b∣ac)P(ac)P(b) = P(b \mid a) P(a) + P(b \mid a ^c) P(a^c)P(b)=P(b∣a)P(a)+P(b∣ac)P(ac)

P(a∣b) =P(a)×P(b∣a)P(b∣ac)P(a)+P(b∣ac)P(ac)P(a \mid b) \ = \frac{P(a) \times P(b \mid a)}{P(b \mid a ^c) P(a) + P(b \mid a ^c) P(a^c)} P(a∣b) =P(b∣ac)P(a)+P(b∣ac)P(ac)P(a)×P(b∣a)​

例题

假设我们有一个袋子，袋子中有5枚均匀的硬币，10枚不均匀的硬币。均匀的硬币得到正面和反面的机会为50%：50%；而非均匀的硬币，假设得到正面的机会为80%，得到反面的机会则是20%。从袋中随机取出一枚硬币，然后把这枚硬币投掷6次。

我们想要知道的是：

问题1、投掷6次，得到4次正面向上的概率是多少？

问题2、在给出投掷6次，得到4次正面的条件下，取出的是一枚均匀硬币的概率是多少？

解决问题1：取出一枚投掷6次，4次正面的概率是多少？

分析：取出一枚枚硬币，得到4次正面的概率应该为 ：

取出一枚均匀硬币，并得到4次正面的概率 + 取出一枚非均匀硬币，并得到4次正面的概率，之和。

假设:

  • 取出均匀硬币为 P(F)，取出不均匀硬币的概率为P(U) ；

  • 投掷6次，得到4次正面的概率为P(4H/6)。

得到4次正面的概率，数学公式表达如下：

P(4H/6)=P(F∩4H/6)+P(U∩4H/6)P(4H/6) = P(F \cap 4H/6) + P(U \cap 4H/6) P(4H/6)=P(F∩4H/6)+P(U∩4H/6)

1） 假设取出的是均匀硬币

取出均匀硬币的概率是:

P(F)=5(10+5)=1/3P(F) = \frac{5}{(10+5)} = 1/3 P(F)=(10+5)5​=1/3

投掷这枚枚均匀硬币6次，得到4次正面的概率是：

P(4H/6∣F)=(64)(0.5)4(1−0.5)2P(4H/6 \mid F) = \binom{6}{4}(0.5)^4(1 - 0.5)^2 P(4H/6∣F)=(46​)(0.5)4(1−0.5)2

取出的是均匀硬币，且得到4次正面的概率是：

P(F∩4H/6)=P(F)×P(4H/6)=1/3×(64)(0.5)4(1−0.5)2=7.8125%P(F \cap 4H/6) = P(F) \times P(4H/6) = 1/3 \times \binom{6}{4}(0.5)^4(1 - 0.5)^2 = 7.8125\% P(F∩4H/6)=P(F)×P(4H/6)=1/3×(46​)(0.5)4(1−0.5)2=7.8125%

2）假设取出的是不均匀硬币

取出一枚不均匀(unfair)硬币的概率是：

P(U)=10(10+5)=2/3P(U) = \frac{10}{(10 + 5)} = 2/3 P(U)=(10+5)10​=2/3

投掷这枚不均匀硬币6次，得到4次正面的概率是：

P(4H/6∣U)=(64)(0.8)4(1−0.8)2P(4H/6 \mid U) = \binom{6}{4}(0.8)^4(1-0.8)^2 P(4H/6∣U)=(46​)(0.8)4(1−0.8)2

取出不均匀的硬币，且得到4次正面的概率是：

P(U∩4H/6)=P(U)×P(4H/6)=2/3×(64)(0.8)4(1−0.8)2=16.384%P(U \cap 4H/6) = P(U) \times P(4H/6) = 2/3 \times \binom{6}{4}(0.8)^4(1 - 0.8)^2 = 16.384\% P(U∩4H/6)=P(U)×P(4H/6)=2/3×(46​)(0.8)4(1−0.8)2=16.384%

最后可得4次正面向上的概率为：

P(4H/6)=P(F∩4H/6)+P(U∩4H/6)=24.1965%P(4H/6) = P(F \cap 4H/6) + P(U \cap 4H/6) =24.1965\% P(4H/6)=P(F∩4H/6)+P(U∩4H/6)=24.1965%

解决问题2：在投掷6次，得到4次正面条件下，取出的是一枚均匀硬币的概率是多少？

P(F∣4H/6)=P(4H/6∣F)P(F)P(4H/6)=7.8125%24.1965%=32.3%P(F \mid 4H/6) = \frac{P(4H/6 \mid F) P(F)}{P(4H/6)} = \frac{7.8125\%}{24.1965\%}=32.3\% P(F∣4H/6)=P(4H/6)P(4H/6∣F)P(F)​=24.1965%7.8125%​=32.3%

参考

可汗学院概率论

entry.title: 一颗旋转小岩石上的一只小猴子🐒
entry.content:
每隔一段时间或遇到不开心的时候，我都会从笔记中把 Naval Ravikant 的这段话翻出来温习一遍，提醒自己：我们不过是一颗旋转小岩石上的一只小猴子...

Monkey on Spinning Rock---Naval Ravikant

“If you study even the smallest bit of science, you will realize that, for all practical purposes, we are nothing. We’re basically monkeys on a small rock orbiting a small, backwards star in a huge galaxy, which is in an absolutely staggeringly gigantic universe, which itself may be part of a gigantic multiverse.

“This universe has been around for probably 10 billion years or more, and will be around for tens of billion years afterwards. So your existence, my existence, is just infinitesimal. It is like a firefly blinking once in the night. Nothing that we do lasts. Eventually you will fade, your works will fade, your children will fade, your thoughts will fade, this planet will fade, the sun will fade . . . it will all be gone.

“There are entire civilizations that we remember now with just one or two words like ‘Sumerian’ or ‘Mayan.’ Do you know any Sumerians or Mayans? Do you hold any of them in high regard or esteem? Have they outlived their natural lifespan somehow? No.

“If you don’t believe in an afterlife, then you [should realize] that this is such a short and precious life, it is really important that you don’t spend it being unhappy. There is no excuse for spending most of your life in misery. You’ve only got 70 years out of the 50 billion or however long the universe is going to be around.”

An excerpt from Tools of Titans - by Tim Ferriss

entry.title: Naval's Quotes on Life Advise_Updateing
entry.content:
Orignally from Naval Ravikant
Sorted by PODCAST NOTES and Me Jamie Liu

The Three Options You Always Have in Your Life

  • "In any situation in life, you only have three options. You always have three options. You can change it, you can accept it, or you can leave it. What is not a good option is to sit around wishing you would change it but not change it, wishing you would leave it but not leaving it, and not accepting it. It's that struggle, that aversion, that is responsible for most of our misery. The phrase that I probably use the most to myself in my head is just one word: accept."

Make Hard Choice

Easy Choices, Hard Life. Hard Choices, Easy Life.---Jerzy Gregorek

  • "Basically if you are making the hard choices right now in what to eat, you're not eating junk food you want and making the hard choice to work out, then your life long-term will be easy. You won't be sick. You won't be unhealthy. The same is true of values. The same is true of saving up for a rainy day. The same is true of how you approach your relationships. If you make the easy choices right now, you overall life will be a lot harder."

Value Your Time

  • Be more conscious of what's a waste of your time

    • "The moment I figure out something is a waste of my time, I leave immediately."

    • Looking back now, Naval realizes most of his past business trips were a waste of time.

    • "Business trips are almost never worth it."

  • "Value your time, it's all you have."

  • "Anytime you can trade money for time, you should, because time is the thing you'll run out of first."

Minimalism

  • Naval recalls a tweet – “Not wanting something is as good as having it”

  • Minimalism is no longer required – what’s required is that your expectations to be just below your means

  • “People who live below their expectations, enjoy a freedom people who are busy upgrading their lifestyles can’t afford.”

    • Don’t keep upgrading your lifestyle every time you make more money – try to live below what you’re earning.

Less Emotion and Anger

  • "Anger hurts you, first and foremost."

  • "We didn't evolve to be angry all the time."

  • "The anger is a hot coal that you hold in your hand while waiting to throw it at somebody."(Buddist saying)

  • What would Naval tell his 23 year old self?

    • "I wish I had done all the same things but with less emotion and less anger."

Happiness

It Won't Make You Happy

  • "Anything you wanted in your life - whether it was a car, wether it was a girl, or whether it was money - when you got it, a year later, you were back to zero. You brain had hedonically adapted to it, and you were looking for the next thing."

Not Happy? Not Smart

  • "If you're smart and capable, you should be able to figure out how to be happy. Otherwise, you're not that smart."

Happiness is a Choice

  • "Happiness is somthing we can learn."

  • "The first step to be happier, is to believe you can be happier."

  • "Just like fitness can be a choice, health can be a choice, nutrition can be a choice, and working hard and making money can be a choice, happiness is also a choice.

Uncondition Yourself

  • A big habit that Naval is working on

    • "I'm trying to turn off his monkey mind."

  • "People are constantly judging everything that they see. They'are playing back movies of things happened yesterday. They're living in fatansy worlds of what's going to happen tomorrow. They're just pulled out of base reality. Actually it's very bad for your happiness."

  • "The mind should be a servant and a tool, not a master. It's not something that should be controlling me and driving me 24/7."

  • "You can uncondition yourself. You can untrain yourself. It's just hard."

Limit Your Desires

  • "Desire is suffering."(Buddha)

  • "Desire is a contract you make with yourself to be unhappy until you get what you want."

    • When you're unhappy about something, just look for the underlying desire that isn't being fulfilled.

  • Happiness is clouded by unlimited desires. Because of this, limit the amount of desire you have.

    • "Pick your one overwhelming desire - it's okay to suffer over that one. But on all the other desires, let them go so you can be calm and peaceful and relaxed."

The Era of Too Much Abundance

Here's the Problem

  • "The Human brain is not designed to absorb all of the world's breaking news and 24/7 emergencies, injected straight into the skull with clickbait headlines. If you pay attention to that stuff, even if you have a sound mind and body, it will eventually drive you insane."

  • "You have social statisticians, scientists, and researchers in lab coats - literally the best minds our generation - figuring out how to addict you to the news. And if you fall for it, if you get addicted, you brain will destroyed."

Here's the Solution

  • "We are overexposed to everthing. The way to survive in modern society is to be an ascetic; it is to retreat from society. There's too much society everywhere you go. You have society in your phone, society in your pocket, society in you ears...It's socializing you and programming everyone. The one solution is to turn it off."

  • Socail Media: "This is the desease of social media - everybody is getting their 5 seconds of fame and becoming a celebrity...but celebrities are the most miserable people in the world."

Avoid Addictions

  • "In a first-world society, success and failure is much more about how you control, manage, and break addictions than it is about going out and doing something."

Supplementary：Life is Short by Paul Graham

  • "One byproduct of technical progress is that things we like tend to become more addictive."

  • "We have to make a conscious effort to avoid addcitions - to stand outside ourselves and ask: is this how I want to be spending my time?"

  • "As well as avoiding bullshit, one should actively seek out things that matter."

    • "One heuristic for distinguishing stuff that matters is to ask yourself whether you'll care about it in the future."

    • "Fake stuff that matters usually has a sharp peak of seeming to matter. That's how it tricks you. The area under the curve is small, but its shape jabs into your consciousness like a pin."

Source:

Book

entry.content:
👏 欢迎使用 Gridea ！
✍️ Gridea 一个静态博客写作客户端。你可以用它来记录你的生活、心情、知识、笔记、创意... ...

Github
Gridea 主页
示例网站

特性👇

📝 你可以使用最酷的 Markdown 语法，进行快速创作

🌉 你可以给文章配上精美的封面图和在文章任意位置插入图片

🏷️ 你可以对文章进行标签分组

📋 你可以自定义菜单，甚至可以创建外部链接菜单

💻 你可以在 Windows，MacOS 或 Linux 设备上使用此客户端

🌎 你可以使用 𝖦𝗂𝗍𝗁𝗎𝖻 𝖯𝖺𝗀𝖾𝗌 或 Coding Pages 向世界展示，未来将支持更多平台

💬 你可以进行简单的配置，接入 Gitalk 或 DisqusJS 评论系统

🇬🇧 你可以使用中文简体或英语

🌁 你可以任意使用应用内默认主题或任意第三方主题，强大的主题自定义能力

🖥 你可以自定义源文件夹，利用 OneDrive、百度网盘、iCloud、Dropbox 等进行多设备同步

🌱 当然 Gridea 还很年轻，有很多不足，但请相信，它会不停向前 🏃

未来，它一定会成为你离不开的伙伴

尽情发挥你的才华吧！

😘 Enjoy~
